moves.1. d4 Nf6 2. Bg5: [%clk 0:05:06] Not a normal start. Let's see what he does after...
moves.2... h6 3. Bxf6 gxf6: [%clk 0:05:07] ...so I'll see if I'm able to handle this and turn it to my advantage.
moves.4. e3: [%clk 0:05:13] Passive play! I know the taget is h5.
moves.4... e5: [%clk 0:05:05] I don't leave him so easily.
moves.5... e4 6. Nfd2: [%clk 0:05:10] Nh4 was more in the spirit of taking advantage of the lack of my g pawn.
moves.6... f5: [%clk 0:05:09] Now I have a stronger center, don't I? And my pieces have easy developement routes, except my lsb. Too bad.
moves.7. Qh5 Qg5: [%clk 0:05:06] Of course! White has no chance than to retreat or...
moves.8. Qxg5 hxg5: [%clk 0:05:10] Who do you think has an edge, here?
moves.9. c4 Nc6 10. a3 Bg7: [%clk 0:05:01] I decided to wait for his pawns and threat c5 later.
moves.11. Nc3 a6: [%clk 0:05:03] Preventing Nb5. I don't intend to castle, of course!!!
moves.12. Nd5: [%clk 0:04:48] No problem, I was just tempting him in doing this too early.
moves.13... Ne7: [%clk 0:04:56] Now white has to help me...
moves.14... Kxe7: [%clk 0:04:59] Thank you, white... Now the situation is much easier for me.
moves.15. Nb3 d6 16. c5 Be6: [%clk 0:05:01] Of course I won't start the exchange, I expect him to do (he shouldn't). But this move puts him in danger.
moves.17. Na5 b6: [%clk 0:04:51] If Nc6+, Kd7 and he N is lost.
moves.18. cxb6 cxb6: [%clk 0:04:53] Same as before, but with Rc8+ in sight.
moves.19. Nc4 Rhc8: [%clk 0:04:52] I wanted to get the N pinned before he could move it. But this allows d5. On the other side, if I play Bd5 so to block the pawn's advance, He has time to move the K or the N.
moves.20. d5: [%clk 0:03:56] Here I missed Bxd5. After RxB, Ke6, the R has to retreat, and then d5 renews the threat. Even so, I got action for my dsb.
moves.20... Bd7 21. Kb1 Rab8: [%clk 0:04:47] Nxb6 will promote exchanges, I don't want them.
moves.22. h4: [%clk 0:03:40] I can react or ignore it.
moves.24. Nc4: [%clk 0:02:39] Here I missed RxN!, and if BxR, bxa3 should be a winner. Instead I went for the slower...
moves.24... bxa3 25. Nxa3 Rc3: [%clk 0:04:15] I'm sure he didn't expect this move from a 1390 player... :-)
moves.26. Nc4: [%clk 0:02:18] Again, RxN gives me advantage. But I played the even more sadistic...
moves.26... Bb5: [%clk 0:04:00] Unpinning the pawn. But I swear that after bxR, BxN+ will lead to mate or near so.
moves.27. Rc1: [%clk 0:02:19] He definitely fears my attack. Ok...
moves.27... Rxc1+ 28. Kxc1 Bxc4 29. Bxc4 Rxb2: [%clk 0:03:40] I think this is stronger than Bxb2+. This also invites white to a last trick!
moves.30. Bxa6: [%clk 0:02:00] ? This will bind white in a bad way...
moves.30... Ra2 31. Bf1: [%clk 0:01:40] Only place to save the B.
moves.31... Ra1+ 32. Kd2 gxh4: [%clk 0:03:50] ... and now the R can take the pawn at the cost of a B. Here, white thought about defend the B so to be free to move the R, and played...
moves.33. Ke2: [%clk 0:01:27] ? ...and with this innocent move, the game is LOST after ONE black move. Can you find it? "Stop the video if you want, and find the right move." :-)
moves.34. Rxh4: As elwoos kindly notes, I missed checkmate in one here. I'm being very polite with my opponent here...
moves.35... Rxf2: [%clk 0:03:43] ...or Rd2+, winning d5. But this will be always there...
moves.37... Rxd5: [%clk 0:03:47] ...defending f4. Now, it should be a piece of cake. It should be.
moves.38. g4: [%clk 0:00:49] White is desperate or careless, and allows the following, too tempting sequence:
moves.43... f6 44. Ke2 Bf4 45. Bg4 d5 46. Bh3: [%clk 0:04:15] Wrong. The K has to pass first, and stop the white B to act.
moves.50. Bf1: [%clk 0:00:49] ...but here is where even the (ehem, ehem...) best fails for overconfidence.
moves.51. Bxe2 dxe2+ 52. Kxe2 Ke4 53. Kf2 Kxf5: [%clk 0:04:30] And this theorical draw, as many moves before. But... coup de scene!
moves.63. Kf1: [%clk 0:01:15] ?? Losing straight away the game! Incredible...

gameName: Being very polite with the opp... :-)
